message.content:
cs.LG, cs.AI, cs.CV, cs.DS, cs.NE 

The paper deals with the problem of efficiently choosing explicit features for risk minimization using finite-dimensional feature maps. This is a common problem in machine learning, which is typically studied in the context of kernel methods. The paper proposes a greedy algorithm for selecting explicit features from multiple kernels, and establishes an out-of-sample error bound that captures the trade-off between approximation error and spectral error. The paper is likely to be classified under cs.LG (Machine Learning), as it deals with a fundamental problem in this field. It may also be classified under cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence), cs.CV (Computer Vision), cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms), and cs.NE (Neural and Evolutionary Computing), as these sub-categories are closely related to machine learning and kernel methods.
